O wretched man, how long wilt thou refuse</br>Thy maker's favour, and his mercy great?</br>How long thy worldly happiness abuse,</br>And growl and grumble at thy present state?</br>Seeking accursed change both soon and late,</br>And newest modes allured still to try—</br>England, beware God's wrath to aggravate,</br>For foreign magic binds thy charmed eye,</br>And Liberty, sweet Liberty, is now the constant cry.

As on my couch in slumber's arms I lay,</br>A vision did my senses entertain;</br>Of late, me thought in France I miss'd my way,</br>Amid a columnless deserted plain;</br>No man or beast upon it did remain,</br>Swept off by Discord's wide destroying strife;</br>Ne planted fence, ne field of waving grain,</br>Marking the toiling farmer's busy life,</br>But ruin'd huts and castles, brent, were wondrous rife.

Yet on this plain, most goodly to behold,</br>Saw I a temple tow'ring to the sky,</br>The dome whereof was made of basest gold,</br>Most false, but yet most lovely to the eye;</br>And rotting pillars reareth it on high,</br>Of ghastly human heads, and clotted gore,</br>With dust, y'mixt the mortar doth supply,</br>While foulest birds still round this temple soar,</br>And filthy serpents hiss, and gaunt hyenas roar.

Among the herds that did the mass compose,</br>Three royal skulls were there — one of a king—</br>Meek saint, who never once revil'd his foes,</br>His bloody foes that him to scaffold bring:</br>One of a maid! — O heaven!  that I could sing</br>With Spencer's tongue, her spotless purity,</br>Her holy zeal, in courts so rare a thing,</br>By lawless fiends condemn'd she was to die,</br>And sent, untimely sent, to seek her native sky.

The third I mark'd with melancholy eyes,</br>A female head, that once a crown did wear,</br>Cut off in life's full bloom, now low she lies,</br>The loose loves weeping o'er her early bier,</br>Nor Virtue's self denies a tender tear;</br>So young a creature, wonder not she fell,</br>And left the paths of chastity severe,</br>Debauched by a Court where lust did dwell,</br>Like treach'rous Circe, skill'd in many a witching spell.

The third I mark'd with melancholy eyes,</br>A female head, that once a crown did wear,</br>Cut off in life's full bloom, now low she lies,</br>The loose loves weeping o'er her early bier,</br>Nor Virtue's self denies a tender tear;</br>So young a creature, wonder not she fell,</br>And left the paths of chastity severe,</br>Debauched by a Court where lust did dwell,</br>Like treach'rous Circe, skill'd in many a witching spell.

Ah!  where are now her gorgeous robes of state,</br>The glitt'ring gems that did her fairness deck?</br>The cringing nobles that on her did wait,</br>The high-born dames that kneeled at her beck?</br>Alas!  a ghastly face, a bloody neck,</br>A simple winding-sheet is now her share;</br>Look here, ye proud ones, on this mighty wreck,</br>And learn what perishable stuff ye are,</br>From her poor mangled carcase, once so sweet and fair.

And on the ground there lay a murder'd child,</br>A piteous sight it was, and full of woe,</br>Who, when alive, by ev'ry art defil'd,</br>With poison, they at last did overthrow.</br>Wretches, who never ruth or conscience know;</br>O lovely flowret cropt by villain hands,</br>How will thy butchers dread th' almighty brow,</br>Arm'd with frowns, when each at judgement stands,</br>And God the meed of murder from his throne commands.

Then o'er the portal was this motto plac'd,</br>"The house of liberty," in gold y'writ,</br>And, ven'tring in, I stood like one amaz'd,</br>Such sights of horror on my heart-strings smit,</br>There Infidelity, in moody fit,</br>Hugg'd Suicide — there Rage, and deadly Fears,</br>There Lechery, with goatish leer did sit,</br>And Murder, quaffing up his victim's tears,</br>With thousand other crimes, too foul for human ears.

In mid the house an image stood in state,</br>Like to Voltaire in visage and in shape,</br>Wither'd, his heart with fellest rage and hate,</br>Shrivell'd and lean his carcase like an ape:</br>And num'rous crowds upon the same did gape,</br>As he all-naked stood to every eye;</br>Above an altar covered with crape,</br>And formed of his books one might descry,</br>Prophane and lewd it was, and cramm'd with many a lie.

And still from 'neath the altar roar'd he,</br>As from a bull lowing in cavern deep,</br>"Come worship me, O men, come worship me;</br>Spit on the cross, of Jesus take no keep,</br>I promise you an everlasting sleep;</br>The soul and body both shall turn to clay;</br>Ye penitents, why do ye sigh and weep?</br>Let no damnation's terrors you affray,</br>Come learn my lore that drives all foolish fears away."

Then in tumultuous haste a number came</br>To this foul fiend, their homage base to pay,</br>Fighting which should be first; O fie for shame!</br>To kiss him on a part I shall not say.</br>And wonder strange their 'haviour and array,</br>As riding upon beasts they hasted on,</br>My feeble pen cannot the whole portray,</br>Yet will I chronicle each leading one,</br>A tedious task, in truth, would heaven that it were done.

The first appeared like to Sathanas,</br>Yet had the daemon neither hoof nor horn,</br>And lo, his bold unblushing front of brass</br>A crown of pikes and poinards did adorn.</br>His garments fouly all were patched and torn,</br>And in his hand he held a begging-box,</br>Whining for charity, like one forlorn,</br>And farthings asking.  O most cunning fox,</br>Full craftily he knew to cant and eke to coax.

His coat was divers colours, red, white, blue,</br>And he was riding on a filthy swine,</br>And oft would ope his beastly mouth to spue,</br>In that same cup, from whence he drank his wine.</br>Behind him sat a lusty concubine,</br>Whom still he kiss'd with wine-distained lip:</br>Painted she was, and deckt in taudry fine,</br>Her eye well skill'd the wanton wink to tip,</br>And hand from doting men their gold away to slip.

Next came that cursed felon Thomas Paine,</br>Mounted upon a tiger fierce and fell;</br>And still a shower of blood on him doth rain,</br>With tears that from the eyes of widow's well;</br>Loud in his ears the cries of orphans yell;</br>The axe impending o'er his head alway,</br>While devils wait to catch his soul to hell,</br>The knave is fill'd with anguish and dismay—</br>And anxious round he looks, even straws to him affray.

The saw I mounted on a braying ass,</br>William and Mary, sooth, a couple jolly;</br>Who married, note ye how it came to pass,</br>Although each held that marriage was but folly?</br>And she of curses would discharge a volley</br>If the ass stumbled, leaping pales or ditches:</br>Her husband, sans-culottes, was melancholy,</br>For Mary verily would wear the breeches—</br>God help poor silly men from such usurping b—s.

Whilom this dame the Rights of Women writ,</br>That is the title to her book she places,</br>Exhorting bashful womankind to quit</br>All foolish modesty, and coy grimaces;</br>And name their backsides as it were their faces;</br>Such licence loose-tongued liberty adores,</br>Which adds to female speech exceeding graces;</br>Lucky the maid that on her volume pores,</br>A scripture, archly fram'd, for propagating w—s.

William hath penn'd a waggon-load of stuff,</br>And Mary's life at last he needs must write,</br>Thinking her whoredoms were not known enough,</br>Till fairly printed off in black and white.—</br>With wondrous glee and pride, this simple wight</br>Her brothel feats of wantonness sets down,</br>Being her spouse, he tells, with huge delight,</br>How oft she cuckolded the silly clown,</br>And lent, O lovely piece!  herself to half the town.

Then came Maria Helen Williams Stone,</br>Sitting upon a goat with bearded chin:</br>And she hath written volumes many a one;</br>Better the idle jade had learnt to spin—</br>Dearly she loves a philanthropic sin</br>Call'd fornication — and doth it commit;</br>Nor careth she for modesty a pin,</br>And laughs at Satan and the burning pit;</br>Ah!  dame!  belike one day you'll know the truth of it.

Next mounted on a monster like a louse,</br>With parchments loaded, came a man of law,</br>Sprung from an ancient Caledonian house,</br>Cunningly could he quibble out a flaw:</br>And this sage man could chatter like a daw,</br>To prove the moon green cheese, and black, pure white,</br>Spitting out treason from his greedy maw;</br>To breed sedition was his chief delight,</br>And scratch men's scabs to ulcers still with all his might.

Then on an Irish bull of skin and bone,</br>A foul churb rode, who still a harp would strum,</br>A harp Hibernian, stringless, saving one</br>Well tun'd to harsh sedition's growling hum:</br>He hit the bull on which he had his bum,</br>Full many a bitter band, nor gave him rest—</br>Dealing his blows on Teague's that round him come,</br>Grieving the while for man and brute oppress'd,</br>Chaunting the Irish howl, abhorr'd of man and beast.

O Ireland, spot accurs'd! — tho' glorious fair,</br>Shines there the sun, the flowers enamell'd blow.</br>And scent, with fragrance sweet, the balmy air,</br>Rippling the gliding pools that softly flow:</br>No noxious reptile there to man a foe</br>Abides — but black revenge with cautious plan,</br>Cool-blooded cruelty with torments slow,</br>Springs rank; with weeds the goodly soil's o'er-ran,</br>And all the reptile's venom rankles in the man.

Then in a gorgeous car of beaten gold,</br>Drove on a portly man, of mighty rank,</br>A person comely, of extraction old:</br>But carrion-like, his reputation stank:</br>Sly was the wight with crafty quip and crank,</br>To cram with glittering coin his bursting bags;</br>Yet whilom taxing-men play'd him a prank,</br>By catching in their traps some stray'd nags,</br>And eke some livery slaves, in miser's livery rags.

Then on a turtle came proud London's Mayor,</br>Follow'd by Aldermen, a frowsy crew,</br>Strong smelling of Cheapside, and luscious fare,</br>Yet apoplexy made his followers few.</br>Long antlers on the head of each man grew,</br>So that they seem'd a host of moving horn;</br>Anon as on they came they'd mump and chew,</br>Stuffing their guts from dawning of the morn,</br>Till shades of evening fell — for eating only born.

On a cock sparrow fed with Spanish flies,</br>A swilling Captain came, with liquor mellow,</br>And still the croud in hideous uproar cries,</br>"Sing us a bawdy song thou d—d good fellow."</br>Incontinent he sets himself to bellow,</br>And shouts with all the strength that in him lies:</br>The Citizetts exclaim "he's sans pareille O!"</br>The Citizens in raptures roll their eyes,</br>And drink, with leathern ears, the fool's lewd ribaldries.

On came these wights, and many more beside,</br>Thick as the grains of sand upon the shore,</br>Thick as a swarm of flies in summer tide,</br>That on a dunghill hive and hover o'er:</br>Most had their hides all scall'd, their trowses tore;</br>Many sans-breaches, shameless trudg'd along,</br>And many a noble knave and titled w—e,</br>With Irish bog-trotters would crowd and throng,</br>Carolling catches base, and filthy French Chanson.

Like roaring waves they cover'd all the plain;</br>And tho' equality they still requir'd,</br>Each cudgell'd sore his breast with might and main,</br>Each to get foremost ardently desir'd.</br>Some fell into the dirt, and foul were mir'd,</br>The rest rode over them and took no head.</br>Their yells, with patriotic ardour fir'd,</br>So made my flesh to quake with very dread,</br>That Morpheus left my couch, and all the vision fled.</br>
